background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">After the confession the condemned-prisoner was sent to Munshiganj Sub-Jail. The confession was specifically brought to the notice of the condemned-prisoner while examining him under section 342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure; but he did not complain anything regarding the nature of his confession. Both the trial Court and the High Court Division therefore rightly believed the confession to be true and voluntary. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Khalil Mia vs State 4 BLC(AD) 223</em></strong><em>.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Sections 164 and 364</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Non-examination of the recording Magistrate of the confessional statement prejudiced the defence denying their right of cross-examining him regarding following formalities under sections 164 and 364, CrPC. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Sanu Mia and ors vs State 3 BLC 441</em></strong><em>.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 164(3)</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Reasonable time for reflection was not given and caution should be given to the accused persons at least twice before recording the confessional statement by the Magistrate who has not fully complied with the mandatory provisions of section 164(3), CrPC, the confessional statement cannot be deemed to be either voluntary or true. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>State vs Raja Abdul Majib &amp; ors 1 BLC 144</em></strong><em>.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 164(3)</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">As the necessary questions were not put to the confessing accused and neither the memorandum nor the seal and designation were given by the recording Magistrate who was cross-examined that the alleged confession was not voluntary and true and that during his remand the confessing accused was severely tortured by the police to make the confession which cannot be accepted as voluntary and true as the confession bears no credibility to base conviction of the accused. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>State vs Md Musa alias Mussaiya alias Shafir Bap 1 BLC 467</em></strong><em>.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 167</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">A Magistrate exercising the power under section 167, CrPC can order police remand for a period not exceeding 15 days in the whole and the Magistrate did not exceed such period by his 3 successive orders of police remand. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>State vs Munir and another 1 BLC 345</em></strong><em>.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 167</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The police having violated the provision of section 167, CrPC in not producing the appellants before any competent Magistrate within 24 hours of their arrest and kept them in police custody for about 2 (two) days without any legal authority, that is without a necessary permission from the Magistrate under section 167, CrPC and such custody of the appellants is illegal resulting thereby the confessional statements are not voluntary and true. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>State vs Sarowaruddin 5 BLC 451</em></strong><em>.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section </strong><strong>167(5)</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">As the stopping of further investigation does not create any <span style="color: black;">vested right in favour of petitioners so as to enable them to the benefit of the repealed provision of sub-section 5 of section 167, CrPC and in the new sub-section there is no such provision for stopping further investigation which takes effect retrospectively, the charge sheet was submitted well within time allowed by the Sessions Judge. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Sultan Ahmed and others vs State 1 BLC 158</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">167(5)</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">Although section 167(5), CrPC enjoins that if investigation is not concluded within 120 days from the date of receipt of the information relating to commission of the offence, the Court, if satisfied, can release the accused person on bail but he cannot claim such bail as a matter of right. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Major (Retd) M Khairuzzaman vs State 3 BLC 344.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Sections </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">167(5) and 498</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">Section 167(5), CrPC provides for releasing an accused person on bail if the Court is satisfied and such satisfaction is wanting. Considering the facts, circumstances, materials on record, nature and seriousness of the offence the discretionary power under section 498, CrPC in granting bail in non-bailable offence cannot be exercised. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Major (Retd) M Khairuzzaman vs State 3 BLC 344</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">167(7A)</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">It is contended that the proceedings of the case was stopped on 12-6-88 but it was revived on 26-7-89 by the learned Magistrate and as per provisions of section 167(7A) of the Code of Criminal Procedure the case was required to be revived on the order of the District Magistrate within six months from the date of stopping the</span> <span style="color: black;">proceedings. Since the case was revived long after the period fixed by the provisions of law the order of revival was illegal and without jurisdiction. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Abdus Samad (Md) vs State 1 BLC 63</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Sections 167 </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">(5)</span></strong><span style="color: black;"> <strong>and 498</strong></span><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">It appears that the petitioner is the accused of the present case and <em>prima facie </em>it is found that he has involvement with the alleged murder of two persons when the Metropolitan Sessions Judge considering the section 167 (5), CrPC has given sufficient reasons in rejecting the prayer for bail warranting no interference. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Tarique Syed @ Mamun vs State 5 BLC 572</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">167(5)</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">On a reading of the amended sub-section 5 of section 167 as effected by the Code of Criminal Procedure (Second Amendment) Act, 1992 it manifests that the time limit of conclusion of the investigation had been totally deleted and in place of that provision of releasing the accused person on bail either by the Magistrate or the Court of Session to the satisfaction of that Court has been provided. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Group Captain (Retd) Shamim Hossain vs State and another 5 BLC 662.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Sections </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">171(2) and 245(1)</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Sub­section (2) of section 171 of the Code provides that it shall be the responsibility of the Police Officer to ensure that the complainant or the witnesses appear before the Court at the time of hearing of the case. It is the primary responsibility of the conducting police prosecutor or the public prosecutor to produce the witness in the case. There is nothing on record to show that any </span><span style="color: black;">step was taken by the prosecution through the police officer to secure the attendance of any witness in the case. The prosecution as a matter of fact failed to produce any prosecution witness and, in such circumstances, the learned Magistrate rightly acquitted the accused respondents under section 245(1) of the Code. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Mobarak Alt &amp; others vs Mobaswir Ali &amp; others 1 BLC (AD) 220.</span></em></strong></span></p></div></div>
775	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Part-2)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  3 BLC (AD) 182, 5 BLC (AD) 153, 5 BLC 636, 5 BLC (AD) 20, 1 BLC (AD) 168, 4 BLC 74, 4 BLC 524, 2 BLC 241, 5 BLC 598, 4 BLC 193, 4 BLC 101, 4 BLC 552, 5 BLC 50, 4 BLC (AD) 228, 4 BLC 74, 3 BLC 148,  5 BLC 672, 1 BLC 312, 3 BLC 474, 3 BLC 591, 5 BLC 386, </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1898</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Code of Criminal <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="37" Name="Bibliography"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">Code of Criminal Procedure, </span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">1898</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">173</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">While considering the police report (FRT) the Special Tribunal heard the learned Advocates of the parties and on perusal of the record and case diary took cognizance, of the offence after observing that a <em>prima facie </em>case was made out by the prosecution but the Tribunal could not agree with the opinion of the investigating officer and took cognizance on the basis of the materials on record. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Bikish Miah vs State 3 BLC (AD) 182.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Sections </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">173(3A) and 265B</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">The statements recorded under section 161, CrPC have not been sent to the trial Court along with the record when such statements are vital documents cannot be withheld from the defence. The accused has every right to look into these statements before any hearing takes place. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Major (Retd) Bazlul Huda vs State 5 BLC (AD) 153.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">173(1)(3B)</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">The police has submitted its report under section 173(1) of the Code and before accepting the same the learned Sessions Judge was pleased to direct for holding further investigation, thus no illegality was committed by directing such further investigation. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Bakul Hossain (Md) vs Md MannafAli and anr 5 BLC 636.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Sections </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">173 and 200</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">The High Court Division took the correct view that the Magistrate had rejected the prayer for judicial enquiry upon misreading the memorandum filed by Superintendent of Police and rightly directed the Thana Magistrate to hold judicial enquiry either by himself or by any other Magistrate. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Sayed Azharul Kabir vs Sayed EhsanKabir 5 BLC (AD) 20.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">173(3B)</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">A co-accused has got no right to apply for further investigation of a case by the Criminal Investigation Department after submission of charge-sheet against him. The Government to decide which case will be investigated by the CID. This is purely an executive action and the Government is free to take any decision for securing proper investigation and for the ends of justice in a case </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Abu Talukder vs Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of Bangladesh and others 1 BLC (AD) 168</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">S</span></strong><strong>ections 173, 190(1) and 561A</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">It is now well settled that a report submitted by the police under section 173 of the Code has no binding force upon the learned Magistrate who is at liberty either to accept the same or to reject it. The learned Chief Metropolitan Magistrate before rejecting the report submitted by the police held a judicial enquiry through another Metropolitan Magistrate and on the basis of the police report as well as the judicial enquiry report took cognizance of the offence which is covered by section 190(1) of the Code and as such the proceeding cannot be quashed. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Nurul Hoque and others vs State and another 4 BLC 74.</em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em> </em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Sections </strong><strong>173</strong> <strong>and 561A</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Sessions Judge has no authority to direct the Magistrate to take cognizance of the offence and such order of taking cognizance by the Magistrate is set aside but the proceeding against the petitioner cannot be quashed and hence the case is sent back to the learned Magistrate for taking steps for holding further investigation. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Hazi Isakur Rahman vs State 4 BLC 524.</em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Sections 179 and 180</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">As from the FIR it <em>prima facie </em>appears that the occurrence took place in Dhaka and then it continued and culminated in Sylhet and in such circumstances the respondent can maintain the case in Sylhet. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Anowara Begum vs Sultana Jeshmine Khan (Shoapa) and State 2 BLC 241.</em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Sections   </strong><strong>195(l)(a)   and   561A</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The learned Magistrate <em>suo motu </em>initiated a proceeding under section 188 of the Penal Code and took cognizance of the offence violating the provision of section 195(l)(a) of the Code of Criminal Procedure providing that no Court shall take cognizance of any offence punishable under sections 172 to 188 of the Penal Code, except on the complaint in writing of the public servant concerned or of some other public servant to whom he is subordinate and hence there is illegality in initiating the proceeding against the petitioner and others and as such the proceedings are quashed. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Abdul Ahad &amp; Md Abdul Ahad vs State 5 BLC 598.</em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section </strong><strong>195(l)(c)</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The allegation against the petitioner is the misappropriation of an amount of money withdrawn from the bank by preparing witnesses' fictitious TA bills while performing administrative duties and such acts are not being a part of any judicial proceeding, the provision of section 195(l)(c) of the Code is not attracted. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Abu Sufian Mia vs State 4 BLC 193</em></strong><em>.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section </strong><strong>195(l)(c)</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Section 195(l)(c) of the Code of Criminal Procedure has reference only to a forged document and not to a copy of it. The Court before which a copy of a forged document is produced is not in a position to determine the genuineness or otherwise of the questioned deed in the absence of the original. The production of the certified copy of a forged document does not, therefore, invoke the bar against prosecution under section 195(l)(c)of the Code. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Nuruddin Ahmed and 2 others vs State 4 BLC 50.</em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section </strong><strong>195(l)(c)</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Section 195(l)(c) of the Code of Criminal Procedure has reference only to a forged document and not to a copy of it. The Court before which a copy of a forged document is produced is not in a position to determine the genuineness or otherwise of the questioned deed in the absence of the original. The production of the certified copy of a forged document does not, therefore, invoke the bar against prosecution under section 195(l)(c) of the Code. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Nuruddin Ahmed (Md) and 2 others vs State 4 BLC 101.</em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section </strong><strong>195(l)(c</strong>)—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">An officer dealing with a miscellaneous case regarding exchange of properties merely acts as an executive authority and does not act as a judicial machinery nor is he invested with any judicial power attracting the provisions of section 195(l)(c) of the Code of Criminal Procedure. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Maniruzzaman alias  Md Maniruzzaman vs State 4 BLC 552.</em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section </strong><strong>195(l)(c)</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Complaint by any other person including police regarding forgery of a document produced in evidence before a Court of law is barred under the provision of section 195(l)(c) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the impugned notice issued by the respondent No. 5, CID Inspector to unnecessarily harass the petitioner to prevent her from proceeding with the legal process for getting delivery of possession of the disputed building and hence the impugned notice is without lawful authority and is of no legal effect. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Gulshan Ara vs Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 5 BLC 50</em></strong><em>.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Sections 195 </strong><strong>(l)(c) &amp; 561A</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Although on the bainapatra in question a title suit is pending but cognizance of the offence was taken not only under section 467 of the Penal Code but also under sections 409 and 420 of the Penal Code and under section 5(2) of Act II of 1947 and as such the criminal case is not barred under section 195 (l)(c), CrPC. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Sadat Ali Talukder (Md) @ Md Sadat AH vs State and another 4 BLC (AD) 228</em></strong><em>.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 200</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Without taking cognizance the petition of complaint having been straightaway sent to the local police by the learned Chief Metropolitan Magistrate for treating the same as FIR where section 200 of the Code has no manner of application. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Nurul Hoque and others vs State and another 4 BLC 74</em></strong><em>.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Sections 200, 204 </strong><strong>(IA)(IB)</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">It is clear from the language of sub-section (IA) and (IB) of section 204 of the Code that taking cognizance of the offence under section 200 of the Code will not be illegal if list of witnesses and a copy of the complaint are not filed before issuance of the process of warrant of arrest or summons and violation of the said provisions cannot make the order of taking cognizance illegal. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Shainpukur Holding Limited vs Security Exchange Commission 3 BLC 148.</em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Sections</strong> <strong>200 and </strong><strong>203</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">There is no requirement of law to record reasons for taking cognizance of an offence under section 200 of the Code but section 203 of the Code requires recording reasons for dismissing a complaint and the CMM applied his mind to the allegations made against the accused persons and on being satisfied took cognizance of the said offence. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Shainpukur Holding Limited vs Security Exchange Commission 3 BLC 148.</em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Sections 203 and 403</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">In the absence of any material before the Court to find that the present case is in respect of the same cause of action constituting a single transaction involving the same set of accused as in the earlier case, the present case is not barred under the law. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em>Tajul Islam and others vs State and another 3 BLC 527</em></strong><em>.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Sections 203, 204 (3) and 436</strong>—</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The powers of the High Court Division or the Sessions Judge in directing enquiry, prior to the commencement of the trial or during trial, are limited in respect of any complaint which has been dismissed under section 203 or 204(3) or into the case of any person accused of an offence who has been discharged and it <span style="color: black;">is not wide enough to invest the Court with power to order further enquiry during trial in all cases. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">State vs Md Joynal Abedin and others 5 BLC 672</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">204(I)(IA)(IB)</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">Admittedly no list of witnesses nor a copy of the complaint (report) was filed by the complainant in compliance with the provisions of section 204(I)(IA)(IB) of the Code before the CMM on 2-4-97 but it appears from the records of CMM's Court that in fact processes of warrants of arrest were not issued at all against the accused persons and as such there was no violation of the provisions of that section. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Shainpukur Holding Limited vs Security Exchange Commission 3 BLC 148</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Sections 221 </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">&amp; 237</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">The appellant was charged under section 412 of the Penal Code but he was convicted under sections 395/397 of the Penal Code under misconception of law which cannot be sustained in law. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Abid Hashem Molla and 5 ors vs State 1 BLC 211.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Sections </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">222(2), 234(1) 342 &amp; 537</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">The defect in framing the charge is curable under section 537, CrPC but for the improper examination of the accused person under section 342 of the CrPC the case is sent back on remand for holding fresh trial in accordance with law. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><em><span style="color: black;">Nizamuddin Dhali (Md) vs State 1 BLC 312</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Sections </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">222(2), 234(1), 517 &amp; 537</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify;
