line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Khalil Mia vs State 4 BLC (AD) 223.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 30</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">Considering the two confessional statements of co-accused implicating the appellant who caused several injuries on the person of the victim three of them from the back side with doubleedged sharp cutting weapon which was recovered from the house of the appellant on the following day of occurrence when almost all the prosecution witnesses supported the prosecution case, the trial Court came to a correct finding that the appellant inflicted three severe injuries and the victim Mozaffar Ali died because of such injuries and hence the conviction and sentence passed by the trial Court against the appellant is affirmed. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Abul Kalam Azad (Md) vs State 5 BLC 162</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 30</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">The husband, Saiful Islam might not have actively participated in the commission of gang rape crime but it was within his prior knowledge and only his resistance or even protest or at least timely intimation to others could have saved her honour and life. Since there was no definite evidence that he instigated the murder of his wife, the offence of the condemned prisoner, the husband does not come within section 6(4) read with section 14 of the Act but comes within section 6(3) read with section 14 of the Act, after considering his </span><span style="color: black;">confessional statement and the attendant circumstances. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">State vs Md Joynal Abedin and others 5 BLC 672.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 30</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">Confession of an accused is not a substantive piece of evidence against the co-accused and such evidence alone without substantive corroborative evidence cannot form the basis of conviction of a co-accused. The High Court Division acted wrongly in treating the confessional statement of co-accused as substantive evidence and treating the evidence of PWs 4 and 7 as corroboration thereof. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Ustar Ali vs State 3 BLC (AD) 53.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">32</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">—Dying declaration</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">The PWs 3, 11, 14, 16, 18 and 21 have univocally stated that deceased Majnu made a dying declaration before PW 14 implicating accused Sabuj, Babul and Golap as his assailants when the defence has not at all challenged the evidence of PW 16 regarding the dying declaration and most of the said witnesses are official witnesses and there is no reason to disbelieve them when dying declaration of the deceased which has degree of sanctity under the law, being the statement of a dying man, on the belief that he being placed in a situation of immediate apprehension of severance of his ties with the mundane affairs, he would not tell a lie and implicate innocent persons on false charges. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Babul Mia and 2 others vs State 5 BLC 197.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">32</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">Merely because the victim died some days after recording the dying declaration will not render the dying declaration inadmissible under section 32 of the Evidence Act. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">State vs Akkel Ali and others 5 BLC 439</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">32</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">It is settled principle of law that a dying declaration should be recorded as far as practicable to record in the language of the declarant but in the instant case, the Magistrate recorded the same in his own language in bonafide and honestly for which it can be believed and mere formality does not stand in the way to minimise the value of dying declaration. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">State vs Abdul Hye Miaji and others 1 BLC 125</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">32</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">Dying declaration if found true can be the sole basis of conviction without corroboration. In this case, that the appellant had threatened the victim with murder and he absconded after the occurrence till his arrest lend assurance as corroboration of dying declaration. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Mostafa (Md) vs State 1 BLC 82.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">32</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">When a man gasps out his story soon after sustaining so many injuries on his person and apprehending imminent death, there is no time for him to fabricate a new story as he is dying and in such circumstances, it cannot be expected that such a man can tell a lie and falsely implicate his enemies with the crime alleged. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">State vs Abdul Hye Miaji and others 1 BLC 125.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">32</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">—PWs 1-7</span></strong> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">mentioning the names of the accused persons that they have inflicted blows by knives and daggers on the person of the deceased which corroborates with dying declaration making it sufficiently strong to warrant conviction. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">State vs Abdul Hye Miaji and others 1 BLC 125</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">33</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">As the investigating officer was examined-in-chief and then he died but </span><span style="color: black;">the defence got an opportunity to cross-examine him but they took adjournment for which the evidence given by him can be accepted under section 33 of the Evidence Act and non-examination of the Investigation Officer will not vitiate the trial. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Abdur Rahman vs State 1 BLC 215</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p></div></div>
786	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Evidence Act (Indian), 1872</h2>

black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">Section 306 of the Penal Code provides for punishment to the person only in the case where a suicide is abetted and intended but unfortunately, there is no provision in our laws to punish such a person whose cruel behaviour drags a married woman to commit suicide but section 113A of the Indian Evidence Act and section 498A of the Indian Penal Code provide punishment in such cases and it is expected our Parliament will enact similar laws. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">State vs Yahiya alias Thandu &amp; ors 1 BLC 185.</span></em></strong></span></p></div></div>
787	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Explosive Substances Act, 1908</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1 BLC 451, 5 BLC (AD) 179, 1 BLC 164, 5 BLC 501.  </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Explosive Substances</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Explosive Substances Act [VI of 1908]</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"><br/> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section 3—</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The allegation made against the appellant is one of causing hurt by ram dao which definitely does not come within the mischief of Explosive Substances Act and the allegation of explosion of bombs has been made in lump but the appellants surrendered before the CMM, Khulna immediately after filing the FIR and he never misused the privilege of bail and as such there should not be any discrimination in granting bail to appellant when other accused persons are enjoying the privilege of bail.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Yonus Member vs State, 1 BLC 451.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><br/> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section 3—</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Although the local witnesses deposed that appellant Mustafizur Rahman caused injury by using an explosive substance but the doctor opined that the injury was caused by a chemical substance when the investigating officer failed to get the injury and the shirt of PW 1 examined by an expert to find out whether PW 1 sustained inury by explosive substance it cannot be said that it is proved that Mustafizur Rahman caused injury by explosive substance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Aminul Islam alias Ranga and others vs State 5 BLC (AD) 179.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><br/> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section 4—</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As the explosive substance was not tested by chemical expert and the seizure list witness even did not know the contents of the polythene bag the alleged recovery from the appellants was not proved and the conviction was set aside.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Mohammad Ali and another vs State 1 BLC 164.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><br/> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section 4—</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">PW 1, the informant, is the sole witness not corroborated by any other independent witness on the point of seizure and recovery of bomb from the convict and such testimony cannot be relied on in the absence of corroboration by independent and unimpeachable evidence as the informant is interested in the result of the case and as such he is entitled to the benefit of doubt and acquitted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Harun Bepari (Md) vs State 5 BLC 501.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
788	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Explosive Substances Act, 1908</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1 BLC 451, 5 BLC (AD) 179, 1 BLC 164, 5 BLC 501, 1 BLC 198</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Explosive Substances </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-08-28</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">Explosive Substances Act, </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">1908</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; color: black;">[VI of 1908]</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 3</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">The allegation made against the appellant is one of causing hurt by ram dao which definitely does not come within the mischief of Explosive Substances Act and the allegation of explosion of bombs has been made in lump but the appellants surrendered before the CMM, Khulna immediately after filing the FIR and he never misused the privilege of bail and as such there should not be any discrimination in granting bail to appellant when other accused persons are enjoying the privilege of bail. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Yonus Member vs State, 1 BLC 451.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">3</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Although the local witnesses deposed that appellant Mustafizur Rahman caused injury by using an explosive substance but the doctor opined that the injury was caused by a chemical substance when the investigating officer failed to get the injury and the shirt of PW 1 examined by an expert to find out whether PW 1 sustained inury by explosive substance it cannot be </span><span style="color: black;">said that it is proved that Mustafizur Rahman caused injury by explosive substance. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Aminul Islam alias Ranga and others vs State 5 BLC (AD) 179.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 4</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">As the explosive substance was not tested by chemical expert and the seizure list witness even did not know the contents of the polythene bag the alleged recovery from the appellants was not proved and the conviction was set aside. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Mohammad Ali and another vs State 1 BLC 164.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">4</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">PW 1, the informant, is the sole witness not corroborated by any other independent witness on the point of seizure and recovery of bomb from the convict and such testimony cannot be relied on in the absence of corroboration by independent and unimpeachable evidence as the informant is interested in the result of the case and as such he is entitled to the benefit of doubt and acquitted. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Harun Bepari (Md) vs State 5 BLC 501.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">5</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">Provisions of the Ordinance have empowered the Court to entertain, try and dispose of any suit relating to five matters including maintenance but such power is not given to a Magistrate under section 488, CrPC but power of Magistrate has not been curtailed consequent to the establishment of the Family Court. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Rezaul Karim vs Rashida Begum and another 1 BLC 198.</span></em></strong></span></p></div></div>

style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; color: black;">[XVIII of 1985]</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">3</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">The contention that the provision of section 3 of the Ordinance overrides other laws so that a person cannot get any relief as provided in any other law if he can get such relief in the Family Courts Ordinance cannot be accepted as a relief provided in an Act cannot be taken away by providing similar relief in a subsequent Act, instead of repealing that provision in the previous Act. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Rezaul Karim vs Rashida Begum and another 1 BLC 198.</span></em></strong></span></p></div></div>

Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">General Clauses Act, 1897</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; color: black;">[X of 1897]</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 6</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Earlier Division Bench of the High Court Division while quashing the proceedings of the Special Tribunal Case did not take into consideration the applicability of section 6 of the General Clauses Act to a case of a repealed statute. The learned Judges of the High Court Division while delivering earlier judgment did not take into consideration two leading decisions wherein it has been held that where an Act repeals an </span><span style="color: black;">earlier Act, and a different intention appears, the repeal shall not affect any liability incurred or punishment incurred in respect of any offence committed against any enactment so repealed and hence the earlier judgment of the High Court Division was given "per incuriam" </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Abul Kalam Khan vs Reaz Morshed and another 5 BLC 528.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 6</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">From the savings clause in section 29 (2)(3) of the Nari-o-Shishu Nirjatan (Bishes Bidhan) Ain, 1995 there is nothing in the language from which it can be concluded that only the cases pending for trial before any Special Tribunal or pending investigation under the Cruelty to Women (Deterrent Punishment) Ordinance, 1983 in its restricted meaning have been saved. If such restricted interpretation is accepted then the accused persons who have committed offence under such repealed enactment will get premium without facing trial which could not be intention of the legislature. The repealing Act does not indicate any intention of destroying the liability or penalty incurred under the repealing Act. In the repealing Act, there is specific mention of only cases which were under investigation or under trial but it does not appear from the repealing Act that the offences, which were committed under the repealed Act which are covered by section 6(b)(c) and (d) of the General Clauses Act, would be deemed to have been destroyed. Section 6 of the General Clauses Act will be applicable unless the new legislation manifests an intention incompatible with or contrary to the provisions of the section. Such incompatibility would have to be ascertained from a consideration of all the relevant</span> <span style="color: black;">provisions of the new law. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Abul Kalam Khan vs Reaz Morshed and another 5 BLC 528.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 6</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">An accused is to be tried in accordance with procedure prevailing on the day trial commenced and if the procedure is changed by the time trial commenced the accused cannot claim vested right to be tried in accordance with the provisions of the repealed procedure. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Sultan Ahmed and others vs State 1 BLC 158.</span></em></strong></span></p></div></div>

was not constituted in accordance with the provisions of section 35 and rule 36 either at the time of trial of the case or at the time of delivery of the judgment and such judgment is also required to be signed by the members constituting the Labour Court and if it is signed only by the Chairman it will not be valid in law. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="32" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="33" SemiHidden="false" mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">Interpretation of Statutes</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">When the occurrence took place then Cruelty to Women (Deterrent Punishment) Ordinance, 1983 was in force, the case instituted after the repeal of the said law can legally be tried under the repealed Ordinance and be governed in accordance with the provisions of Cruelty to Women (Deterrent Punishment) Ordinance, 1983 as if the said law had not been repealed by Nari-o-Shishu Nirjatan (Bishes Bidhan) Ain, 1995 which came into force on 17-7-95 and the occurrence of the present case took place on 12-5-95 and hence it cannot be said that this case will be governed by the said Ain of 1995 with retrospective effect and as such there is an error of law in taking cognizance of the offence under the said Ain of 1995. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Abul Kalam Khan vs Reaz Morshed and another 5 BLC 528</span></em></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"> <span style="color: black;">Jail Code, [ix of 1894]</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Rules 617, 979-981 and 1051 to 1058</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">A condemned prisoner, in view of section 30 of the Prisoners Act, 1894 and the Rules 617,</span> <span style="color: black;">979 to 981 and 1051 to 1058 of the Jail Code is not entitled to get Division I, although under-trial prisoner in this case may get Division 1 but there will be serious difficulty in allowing the facilities prescribed for Division-I as the condemned prisoner shall be confined in a cell apart from all other prisoners and shall be kept under constant charge of a guard and if the condemned prisoner is awarded Division 1 it will create a dangerous situation and anomaly in jail administration. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Major (Retd) Bazlul Huda vs State 5 BLC 254.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">Paragraph 910</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">As the petitioner was an army personnel, served in Bangladesh Embassy in different countries and lastly, he was Director-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the rank and status of a Joint Secretary, which amply prove that he had a habit of life leading to a superior mode of living attracting the paragraph 910 of the Jail Code entitling him to Division I in the jail which was also admitted by the other side, Besides that some of the co-accused have already been granted Division I and the petitioner is, on the same footing, entitled to be granted Division I status in the Dhaka Central Jail as under trial prisoner. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Major (Retd) M Khairuzzaman vs State 2 BLC 646.</span></em></strong></span></p></div></div>

no prayer for adjournment was made by him for making </span><span style="color: black;">preparation of the defence case it is decided that learned Advocate got reasonable time to get ready to conduct the case. In the absence of any evidence it cannot be said that the concerned Advocate was not a senior lawyer. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">State vs Firoj Miah and another 5 BLC 1.</span></em></strong></span></p></div></div>

1976</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">64(2)</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">In exercising the power under section 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure to do real justice this Court cannot help a person who is flouting an order of a Court on mere technical ground and thereby helping him in avoiding the payment of fine imposed by a village Court which shall be </span><span style="color: black;">recovered by Union Parishad concerned in accordance with Local Government Ordinance, 1976. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Nur Mohammad Khan vs Abdul Jabber Munshi and State 1 BLC 17.</span></em></strong></span></p></div></div>
797	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Martial Law Regulation No. 11 of 1975</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1 BLC 135</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1975</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Martial Law</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><br/> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Martial Law Regulation No. 11 of 1975</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"><br/> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Case was pending before Summary Martial Law Court—After withdrawal of Martial Law the Criminal Court is to proceed with the trial afresh—As the proceeding was pending before the Summary Martial Law Court where certain witnesses were examined and after withdrawal of Martial Law the Divisional Special Judge was required under the law to proceed with the trial afresh but he disposed of the case on the evidence recorded by the Summary Martial Law Court without adopting such evidence and noticing that the Court of Special Judge was not a succeeding Court of Martial Law Court, the trial Court committed gross illegality in disposing of the case on the evidence recorded by the Summary Martial Law Court which cannot be sustained and the case was sent back to the Divisional Special Judge for holding fresh trial.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Saidur Rahman vs State 1 BLC 135.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">Narcotics Control Act, 1990</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; color: black;">[XX of 1990]</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 19</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">As the respondent was carrying surreptitiously 3 kg 27 grams of powder the whole stuff is to be treated as heroin for the purpose of the Act intending to punish the carrier of the narcotic irrespective of whether it is in the purest form or not. It is</span> <span style="color: black;">not necessary for the prosecution to prove the "actual and real heroin content" for the purpose of a conviction under clause l(a) of the table of section 19 of the Act. The view taken by the High Court Division expressing that the purpose of the law is only to punish the preparation, carrying and dealing, etc, of 'laboratory heroin' and not the stuff is wrong. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">State vs Miss Eliadah McCord 2 BLC (AD) 1.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 19</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">While considering the sentence to be passed upon the respondent under clause l(a) of section 19 of the Act the High Court Division was wrong in relying upon a statement made by the respondent recorded in connection with the Miscellaneous case started on a <em>suo inotu </em>Rule as that statement was not part of the record of the appeal and thus irrelevant as fat-as the appeal was concerned. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">State vs Miss Eliadah Mc Cord 2 BLC (AD) 1.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 19</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">As there is no scope for altering the conviction from one under clause l(b) to clause l(a) of the table of section 19 of the Act reducing the sentence on compassionate ground considering the age of the respondent who may approach the Government or the President, if so advised, for any relief that she may choose to pray. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">State vs Miss Eliadah Mc Cord 2 (AD) BLC 1.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">19(7) <span style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">(Kha)</span></span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">The seizure list witnesses having not supported the prosecution case of recovery of two bags of ganja from the possession of the appellant when the evidence of Habilder, a member of raiding party, made the recovery of the incriminating articles as he testified that the </span><span style="color: black;">seizure list was prepared at Ferry-Ghat when none of the neighbours were called at the time of recovery and hence the prosecution has failed to prove the alleged recovery of incriminating articles beyond reasonable doubt and thus the judgment and order of conviction and sentence is set aside. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Musa Miah vs State 5 BLC 703</span></em></strong><em><span style="color: black;">.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Sections 19(1), 6(Kha), </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: black;">22(Ga) <span style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">and </span>25</span></strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;">In the absence of any provision as to in which court the offence under triable the provisions of section 5(2), CrPC will apply and the trial should be held in the Court as mentioned in the second schedule to the Code of Criminal Procedure under the heading "offences against other laws". </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana, geneva, sans-serif;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">Arjun Saha and ors vs State 5 BLC 416.</span></em></strong></span></p></div></div>
